title: Should I take the SAT or ACT? I'm much better at math than reading. - Quora

response.answer_text: Asha Mehta gave false information. The schools each have their own test score submission policies. Some schools make you submit all your scores, others only allow you to send in your best composite, etc. It’s all up to the school. The same applies for the ACT. Concerning which test to take–it’s more about how your brain works really. I highly encourage you to try both tests to see which one you like better–which one “feels” easier. The SAT gives your more time per question, but they tend to be trickier and not so straight forward. The ACT gives you less time, but the questions are more blunt and don’t ask much about inferencing. If you’re more of a critical thinker and a philosopher try the SAT. If you’re a quick thinker and a pragmatist try the ACT. All in all, unless financial burdens become an issue, take both and see which one you like. To my knowledge, no school requires you to submit ACT and SAT scores, so don’t worry about taking them both.
In short: the SAT should be a better test for you. Take a look at this infographic to help you decide further.

A major advantage of the ACT is that you can choose which of your tests to send in, whereas you have to send in all your SAT scores. Colleges are also starting to value the ACT more and more. Finally, if you are good at science, you may want to consider the ACT. However, if you are better at other subjects, take the SAT

Take an official practice test for both and see how you go. Math is half the SAT and only 25% of the ACT. If you are outside the States, look hard at the SAT as the ACT’s transition to a computer-based format has been a bit of a mess.
